title: Friday, 28th October, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

PM

PM

Let me get a pic up

PM

PM

PM

with his wife

PM

PM

Former GRE fund manager

PM

PM

Harry known as Little Harry, cos he's a short arse

PM

International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 435.06, up 21.56 (+5.21%), High: 435.13, Low: 409.30, Volume: 7.29m
11:11 am
BE

Headlines relentlessly negative on the wires etc. Lots of reference to cutting forecasts.

BE

Which is true, but misses the fact that the consensus had already baked in the lower forecasts.

BE

So it's in line. In fact it's better than in line because there's a 10% dividend bump.

11:12 am
PM

That's a hike in these conditions

BE

And one can argue that BA -- whatever you call it, thingmy -- is increasingly looking like a yield play.

BE

Note the 4% divi, but also the potential for 6% plus

11:13 am
BE

Based on the pension trustee agreement earlier in the week, that we talked about a bit here.

PM

Airlines as a yield play. Who'd have thought

BE

https://www.ft.com...-8f9b-70e3cabccfae

11:14 am
BE

That was the idea of making a conglomerate flag carrier. Reliable-ish cashflow rather than hypercyclical.

BE

Let me grab Citi to summarise the headlines.

BE

3Q16 results in line with our expectation and consensus
Pre-exceptional operating profit of €1,205m (18.6% margin) was in line with our expectation of €1,208m (18.3% margin) and consensus of €1,209m (source: IAG) but was slightly down from €1,250m (18.5% margin) in 3Q15. Net income of €970m was better than our expectation of €856m due to non-operating cost of only €33m vs. our expectation of minus €116m and disruption costs came to €40m. Operating profit was overall negatively affected by currency by €162m, mainly due to the weakness of GBP versus Euro and US dollar.

11:14 am
BE

Underlying unit revenue as expected
Passenger unit revenue per ASK (RASK) fell by 13.7%, slightly worse than our expectation of -12%. Excluding currency effects, it fell by 5.9%, which is in line with our expectation of -6.3%. The negative currency impact on revenue of -7.8%, primarily due to the weakness of GDP, was slightly worse than our expectation of -5.7%. Total revenue of €6,486m was less than our expectation of €6,601m but was offset by total operating costs of €5,281m being less than our expected €5,393m.

BE

FY16 outlook better than expected but in line with consensus
IAG expects to make an operating profit of €2.5bn, which is higher than our expectation of €2.33bn and 7% higher than €2.33bn in 2015. Implied 4Q16 operating profit is €585m, higher than our expected €407m and 10% higher than €510m in 4Q15. There has been no change in short-term trading conditions. IAG increased its interim dividend by 10% to €0.11 form €0.10, which is better than our flat expectation. It expects to make a FY16 DPS of €0.22 vs. €0.20 expected.
Implications
We maintain our Buy (1) rating. We believe P/E of less than 6x is good value.

BE

"PE sub six!?" I said. But apparently, yes, PE sub six.

11:15 am
BE

PM

Blimey

PM

Credit Suisse also enthusiastic

11:15 am
PM

Neil Glynn there

PM

New era to produce new levels of efficiency and cash flow generation
despite demand doubts: We expect three key themes at upcoming CMD on
4 November: (i) increased comfort on premium cabin health: IAG's
premium volume performance, and rising published BA premium fares
suggest top line resilience in the face of increasing demand doubts, (ii) selfhelp
beyond 2020 targets – question of how much can boost earnings:
we anticipate new BA CEO Alex Cruz will unveil new self-help initiatives
focused predominantly on achieving the next level of efficiency at BA – we
see €1bn of additional opportunity beyond current plans (39% of 2016E
EBIT), and (iii) future cash distributions potentially compelling, subject
to revenue resilience: with BA's requirement to top up its NAPS deficit
capped at £150m beyond fixed £300m annual payments, versus a prior
requirement to match dividends with top ups, we expect cash distributions to
shareholders to build as a theme. We expect this may begin with the
dividend payout ratio upped from 25% to 35% in due course, but see a lot of
targeted €1.5bn-€2.5bn annual FCF as distributable (7.5-12.6% of mkt cap).

PM

New era

11:16 am
PM

Hmm

PM

Glynn's target price is 469p

BE

And for completeness, Goodbody off the conrecent call.

11:17 am
BE

- September was good for IAG and industry as a whole. Management were keen to be cautious as to this being a trend but suggested it could be the bottoming of market with regards yield weakness.
- IAG continuing to moderate growth. Started FY16 with a target of 5.5% ASK growth, ending the year closer to 4.4%. Stated that this will continue into FY17 and that they were seeing this happening across the industry.
- Premium leisure has been good. We see this as reflecting demand out of the US in the main. Still positive about North Atlantic market as competitors take capacity out of Heathrow. Our numbers suggest overall seat capacity will be down 1.7% yoy Heathrow to US in Q1 next year but with BA up 0.6% for a 90bp improvement in market share to 38%.

BE

"conrecent" means conference. Though I'll claim it as a neologism.

BE

- Talking to the company before, the suggestion is that the mix on the North Atlantic is changing with modest seat growth due to more ‘Super-high J’ 747s being utilised (configuration with 86 business class seats vs 70 and 145 economy seats vs 185).
- Engineering outsourcing becoming more of a feature.
- ‘Initial’ exceptional charge of €62m relating BA staffing means that we should expect more on this front in Q4 and FY17.
- Overall ex-fuel unit cost target for FY16 stands at -1%, suggesting closer to -4% yoy in Q416. This improving trend will run through next year (although no commitment made as to the rate yoy).
- We will be moving our FY16f operating profit from €2.4bn to €2.5bn (market consensus).
- First thoughts of our under review FY17 operating profit forecast is to move from €2.3bn to €2.6bn.
- Stock remains attractive on sub-6x PE, Yield of 5% and ROCE of 14%.

11:19 am
BE

I'm sure there's a reason why IAG would be on a 6x and EasyJet's on 9x.

PM

The Spanish side, i guess

BE

Yeah, union risk and pension liability and blah blah blah.

11:20 am
BE

But note where GBP composite AA bonds are going ....

BE

In addition to the entirely benign-to-good pensions agreement earlier in the week, we've got yields sprinting higher and taking another £1bn or so off that deficit.

PM

thumbs up

11:22 am
BE

Dunno. I'm not saying buy BA, but I might if I had to.

BE

Some of the one-offs are probably not one-offs and some of the core is probably not core.

BE

But where you put things really is a matter of interpretation. I advise deciding whether you want to buy or sell then finding the numbers required to justify that argument, because all possible conclusions can be reached fairly easily.

11:31 am
PM

Just reading some Trader Gordon on this

PM

PM

Welcome to Markets Live

11:31 am
PM

An Attributable Loss of £469m is in line with our estimate (£471m) but £238m (103%) below consensus (£231m), and reflects restructuring (£0.5bn), conduct (£0.4bn) and deferred tax asset writedowns (£0.3bn). As such, tNAV per share declined by 7p QoQ to 338p, (INVe forecast 337p, consensus 348p). However, underneath all this, the “core” business continues to deliver a perfectly respectable performance, with “Adjusted” Operating Profit of £1.3bn – a remarkable 82% beat, but on 0.7x 2017e tNAV we are cautious. SELL.

BE

And Goodbody, again.

BE

RBS Group reported its results for the nine months ending 30th September 2016 this
morning. While the Group posted a headline net loss of £469m in Q3 (Q315: +£940M), the
reported adjusted operating profit of £1.3bn was a significant improvement on Q315
(£826m) owing to higher non-interest income and significantly lower operating costs,
partially offset by reduced impairment charges.
The key points of note in the release were: i) NIM slipped to 2.17% in Q3 from 2.21% in Q2
owing to margin pressures; ii) adjusted Cost/Income of 58% for the nine months to end
September; iii) strong growth in residential mortgages and commercial lending volumes; iv)
FLCET1 ratio up 50bps in the quarter to 15.0% (mainly due to RWA reduction); and v)
leverage ratio up 40bps to 5.6%. On the outlook: i) long-term targets of 12%+ RoTE and
Cost/Income

11:32 am
BE

RBS’s progress in growing revenue and taking out costs as well as its relatively
strong asset quality are clearly positive trends. However, risks to NIM accruing
from a structurally lower interest rate environment, uncertainties around the
quantum of further litigation and conduct charges, and potential involuntary RWA
intensity uplift are all factors that may continue to weigh on the stock, which
currently trades at 0.58x end-Q316 Tangible Book Value.

BE

(@CommentGoesHere: very fair summary.)

BE

Wigmore Street Investments No. 3 Limited, in fact, which is really CERCL Holdings.

BE

Which is really Zdenek Bakala.

PM

Sold at 110p apparently

11:36 am
PM

Zdenek's a cheery chap

PM

PM

Guess he's just pocketed £70m

11:37 am
BE

We can bury ourselves in the history here, with New World Resources etc, but instead let's just go for the facts. Sold at 110p a share and locked in for an entire 90 days.

BE

Quick line from Dragon Capital ......

BE

Prior to the sale, CERCL Holdings Limited was the second largest shareholder
of Ferrexpo with a 23.8% stake. It now holds a stake of close to 13.2%. We estimate the GBp
110/share price implies an average pellet price of $75/t in 2017 and C1 production costs of
around $32/t valued at EV/EBITDA of 6x. While we find such estimates aggressive, the deal
price is likely to serve as a benchmark for the upper bound of Ferrexpo’s share price in the
short term.

11:38 am
BE

Now, this is rather regrettable timing as Ferrexpo management had an investor dinner this week.

BE

Which Citi can summarise, since they went along.

BE

As expected their outlook on pellet premiums (the main earnings driver currently) and Ukrainian country risk (the main investor concern) were the highlights:

11:39 am
BE

The perfect storm for pellet premium will abate

While the company is happy about pellet premiums at well over $40/t, management points out that the current pellet premium as a percentage of iron ore price is at 75%-100% of next year's consensus iron ore price compared to previous highs of 40-50%. This situation looks unsustainable in the medium term, according to the company.

Coking coal price downturn the most tangible near-term risk to pellet premium

High pellet premiums can be attributed to a combination of a) Samarco being out of production, with 30mn t/yr not available in a 250 t/yr market; b) High coking coal prices, which have dou‎bled in the last 7 months and hence driven demand for blast furnace premiums; c) Stronger-than-expected end-steel demand conditions. Ferrexpo expects coking coal prices to moderate over the coming months, while the timeline for a Samarco restart remains uncertain.

BE

Strong cashflow to be used in the near term to degear the balance sheet further

The company is looking for Net Debt/Ebitda of less than 1x (compared to 2.5x at end 1H’16) before it looks at strategic options for growth. Incremental expansions at Belanovskoye, acquisitions or JVs are all on the table.

Situation at Ukraine is improving, according to Ferrexpo

Operating conditions are better this year than last year. The company is operating with substantially lower cash balances held in Ukraine after the issues last year and, as a result, it is seeing higher C1 costs in its operations – but this is necessary for risk management, according to the company.

BE

They're sellers.

11:39 am
PM

Hadn't appreciated how this thing has recovered

PM

It was 21p at the beginning of the year

BE

Yeah, you'll remember when Zhevago's bank collapsed at the back end of 2015

11:40 am
BE

With most of Ferrexpo's money in it.

BE

Which raised .... how do I phrase this? .... a few new concerns about corporate governance.

BE

What's happened since is that China's directly targeted its steel industry, pellet prices have jumped and the stress on Ferrexpo's balance sheet has been alleviated. Absolutely nothing to do with company actions.

11:42 am
BE

But it was being priced for a rather high risk of failure less than a year ago, and isn't any more.

Gulf Keystone Petroleum Ltd (GKP:LSE): Last: 1.26, down 0.01 (-0.79%), High: 1.29, Low: 1.26, Volume: 10.78m
undefined
BE

Sellside wise, we have Morgan Stanley with a deep dive into student digs.

11:48 am
Unite Group PLC (UTG:LSE): Last: 560.00, down 22 (-3.78%), High: 568.00, Low: 543.00, Volume: 775.19k
BE

"Fewer" is the gist.

BE

#1: We think that international student numbers could fall as a result of
potential stricter visa rules for non-EU students, who make up 25% of Unite’s
tenants, and because EU students, which make up 9% of Unite’s tenants, face
tuition fee hikes post Brexit vote – university applications from EU students are
already down 9% for the academic year starting Sep 17.

11:49 am
BE

Also, poverty and etc.

BE

#2: Falling affordability for UK students: UK students have formed the majority
of the increase in undergraduate student numbers in recent years, and
penetration has grown more among the less affluent than the more affluent.
Less well off students are likely to face increasing affordability issues:
i) maintenance grants have been converted to repayable loans, affecting 20% of
students (half of whom see the grant as essential for their studies); ii) tuition fees
may rise more from 2017; iii) 77% of recent graduates are worried about their
student debt.

BE

... as well as an impending glut of bedsits and fleapits.

11:50 am
BE

#3: Risk of oversupply and softening yields: We estimate the current pipeline of
purpose built beds equates to about a quarter of existing beds. According to our
channel checks, pockets of oversupply are appearing in some markets and
demand for secondary assets is softening.

BE

......... So!

BE

Impact on our numbers and rating: We cut rental growth from 4% to 3% pa, and
now assume 25bp yield expansion by Dec-17 (was 5bp) – our Dec-17 NAV falls by
10%. We increase our target discount to 8% (was 0%) – we are taking away the
4% premium for exposure to student assets and the 4% for developments. We
arrive at a price target of 590p (was 700p) (on par with the share price) which
puts it into the bottom third of our order of preference, thus the downgrade to
Underweight. The timing of our downgrade may not be perfect, but we see a
higher likelihood of negative than positive newsflow ahead. We would become
more positive if Unite were to expand in growth markets abroad.

11:51 am
PM

I think those arguments are very strong

PM

It is absolutely the case that students are thinking twice before signing up for £50k of debt by the age of 21

PM

And the prices charged for halls of residence are now eye-watering

11:52 am
PM

Upwards of £200 a week for a room 6ft wide

BE

On the flipside, my hometown has two universities, both of which massively overbuilt accommodation before getting their funding cut aggressively.

BE

They advertise for tenants with posters about 42 inch tellies and fibre broadband.

11:53 am
PM

Also, why are we stinging the young generation with student debt cost of 3/4%??? All this could be refinanced with gilts and basically close to zero %

BE

On the assumption that they won't pay it, I'd guess.

BE

But yes. In C-list towns, there's not much need for the private sector to step in because there's a glut of university-owned digs. And in the A-list cities -- London, Edinburgh, wherever -- there's a supply crush. I don't envy students these days.

11:55 am
PM

(Bluesky21 -- repayments start automatically when the graduate is earning £20k. Interest is charged from the point of drawdown, when the student is a student)

BE

BE

(Let the transcript note that I paid off my student loan in full, having spent every single penny in Fopp and Avalanche Records.)

11:57 am
undefined
BE

Oh, and we should mention Just Eat.

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 521.00, up 14.5 (+2.86%), High: 522.00, Low: 501.00, Volume: 1.35m
11:58 am
PM

What's the story there?

BE

Nothing much. Just Berenberg saying buy on weakness.

BE

Berenberg are fans of all sorts of stocks we're not terribly keen on.

11:59 am
BE

It takes a difference of opinion to make an etc.

BE

The UK weather will not always be warm; we reiterate Buy: Just Eat’s
share price increased by 40% through the summer but has given back some
of its gains primarily as a result of an expected weaker Q3 UK order growth
rate. With a tough comparable from a wet Q3 last year, the unseasonably
warm Q3 2016 will result in a softer yoy UK growth rate, in our view.
However, with Domino’s (and many other UK retailers) reporting similar
trends, we see any slowdown as unfortunate but temporary and not
something that materially affects the medium-term growth story. Let us
not forget that Just Eat’s H1 results were characterised by a large beat and
an upgrade to 2016 guidance. Our UK order Q3 growth rate of 26% is
broadly in line with consensus. We view recent – and any upcoming –
weakness as an opportunity for investors and reiterate our Buy rating.

BE

Currency a key driver of forecast upgrades: With around a third of
revenues coming from outside the UK, sterling weakness since Brexit
provides a material revenue tailwind. While these regions collectively have
limited EBITDA in 2016, their growth results in larger upgrades to EBITDA
in the outer years. Just Eat’s H1 beat and guidance upgrade made our
underlying growth rates look somewhat prudent. We also adjust for a
weaker UK Q3 and the disposal of the Benelux businesses. The net impact
leads us to upgrade our revenues by 2.5-5% over the forecast period. As has
become customary, we expect the company to re-invest some of the H1
beat to drive further growth, but increase our 2017-18 EPS estimates by 2%.

12:00 pm
BE

Supplier deals provide significant upside optionality: Given that Just Eat
has over 27,000 takeaway restaurants as customers in the UK (of which
more than 95% are independent), the company has far greater bargaining
power than its restaurant partners. In recent months, Just Eat has
announced deals with Booker and Coca-Cola, and we expect the company
to sign many more deals to provide restaurant partners discounts in areas
such as credit card fees, insurance and utilities. We believe that these deals
could not only create an attractive revenue opportunity, but more
importantly in our view, we believe that either through natural selection or
exclusivity, the appeal of using competitors will be diminished.

BE

Upside remains, valuation compelling: We remain of the view that Just
Eat is extremely well positioned to take advantage of the ongoing
migration of takeaway orders from offline to online. Our new DCF suggests a
fair value of GBp600, offering c20% upside. In terms of multiples, the
company trades on a 2017 EV/EBITDA and P/E of 19.8x and 30.2x
respectively, a c20% premium to listed peers. If we look one year forward
to 2018, multiples are a touch above peers but Just Eat will still offer far
superior earnings growth. In our view, this warrants a premium rating.

BE

So, there. That. Thus.

12:00 pm
undefined
PM

It's midday

PM

But note one curiousity..

12:01 pm
PM

Global Lender Equities First Holdings Returns Shares of ANGLE plc and Concludes Transaction in the United Kingdom

PM

http://www.investe...1610280845026765N/

PM

INDIANAPOLIS, IN--(Marketwired - Oct 28, 2016) - Equities First Holdings, LLC (EFH, www.equitiesfirst.com), a global lender and a leader in alternative shareholder financing solutions, announced today that the company has fully concluded a transaction with Andrew Newland, CEO of ANGLE plc, by returning 1.35 million shares of ANGLE plc (AIM: AGL.LN) (OTCQX: ANPCY) stock to him, which was used as collateral in a financial transaction.

This two-year financing facility, originated on October 27, 2014, was one of EFH's first transactions executed in the United Kingdom after the acquisition of Meridian Equity Partners Limited. EFH acquired Meridian in the summer of 2014 and rebranded the acquired operation as Equities First (London) Limited.
